I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The regional knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will support the Greater 
Mekong Railway Association (GMRA)1 in accelerating the development of rail connections among 
0F
the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) countries2 by (i) improving the organizational structure of 
1F
the GMRA; (ii) preparing an operational readiness plan to ensure appropriate standards for 
technology on safety, productivity, and environmental quality of railway operations; (iii) updating 
the  GMS  railway  strategy  for  the  development  of  missing  cross-border  railway  links  and 
associated domestic connections; (iv) updating the Mekong (Sub-) Regional Transport Model 
(MRTM) prepared under phase 1 of the TA for Connecting the Railways of the Greater Mekong 
Subregion, enhancing the capacity to utilize it effectively;3 and (v) identifying bankable railway 
2F
projects in GMS countries.4 
3F
 
2.  The TA is not included in any current country operations business plan or regional country 
operations business plan, any Asian Development Bank (ADB) Management-approved annual 
work program of the Southeast Asia Department or a sector or thematic group, or any endorsed 
corporate priority. The TA was discussed and agreed with the GMS countries during the third 
GMRA board of directors’ meeting in Vientiane, Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) on 
22 March 2018. GMS countries expressed strong support for the TA and appreciation of the 
continued support of ADB to the GMS program. Further discussion on the implementation of the 
TA was held during the GMRA negotiation meeting on 24 May 2019 at ADB headquarters.5  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  While all GMS countries are well connected by a road network and are signatories of the 
Trans-Asian Railway agreement,6 they still lack connectivity by rail.7 They have weak and older 
4F 5F
railway  systems  with  missing  cross-border  links,  delayed  provision  of  cross-border  railway 
infrastructure, and inadequate regional rail agreements. To enhance railway connectivity in the 
GMS, the GMS countries have identified and agreed upon nine missing cross-border rail links. 
The GMRA agreed on and endorsed these nine rail links at its first general meeting on 12 March 
2015 in Kunming, People’s Republic of China (PRC). Phase 1 identified priorities for development 
of the missing rail links and preliminary indications of the optimum sequencing for the physical 
development of the future railway network (footnote 3). It also identified the need to develop the 
future railway network in consideration of the current developments in railway technology already 
common in the PRC and many other countries; and emerging developments in train control, train

Viet Nam.

(https://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/project-documents/42518/42518-024-tcr-en.pdf).  
4  ADB. 2013. Technical Assistance Completion Report: Planning the GMS Railway Coordination Office. Manila.

6  The Trans-Asian Railway agreement was signed on 10 November 2006, facilitated by the United Nations Economic 
and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific. 
7  In the GMS, only Thailand–Cambodia (Poipet–Border Bridge–Aranyaprathet) and Thailand–Lao PDR (Nong Khai–
Friendship Bridge–Thanaleng) were linked by railways as of July 2019. The Kunming–Hai Phong railway corridor 
(connecting the PRC and Viet Nam) is operational, except for a missing link at the border, where a gauge change is 
required.

2 
 
operations, motive power, and communications. Although phase 1 made good progress with the 
prioritization of the missing railway links, it is essential to (i) define the emerging changes in 
railway technologies and their potential impact on GMS railway operations and investment, (ii) 
conduct further detailed analysis of what is appropriate given the legacy investment in railway 
infrastructure,  and  (iii)  continue  consultation  with  national  railway  organizations  that  have 
inadequate cross-border railway transport capabilities. 
 
4.  The GMRA was established in 2012 to promote the development of a seamless GMS rail 
network by (i) agreeing on technical standards of interoperability, and (ii) streamlining and 
harmonizing procedures for cross-border movement of goods and people. However, the GMRA’s 
current structure is not ideal to address future coordination of GMS railway development, and the 
introduction and standardization of technologies.8 Since its inception, the GMRA has made efforts 
6F
to better define and formalize its role, and to determine how best to fund its operations. Given 
recent developments in the GMS, including the construction and planning of several new cross-
border railway links, enhancing the technical capability and coordination function of the GMRA 
would be beneficial to all GMS countries. An institutionally strengthened GMRA would, among 
other things, be able to accommodate appropriate technologies, which would lead to increased 
safety and railway productivity, and reduced adverse environmental impacts. 
 
5.  The GMRA seeks to accelerate railway connectivity by promoting efficient, safe, reliable, 
and environmentally sustainable rail transport of goods and people within and beyond the GMS. 
ADB’s TA for Support for Implementing the Action Plan for Transport and Trade Facilitation in the 
Greater Mekong Subregion helped to prepare and finalize the Framework Agreement on Cross-
Border Railway Transport Connectivity in the GMS.9 The Framework Agreement was discussed 
7F
among GMS countries on 24 May 2019 at ADB headquarters and will subsequently be subject to 
further negotiation and the national ratification processes of the GMS countries. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
6.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: greater railway connectivity in the GMS 
provided.10 The TA will have the following outcome: GMRA functioning with adequate capacity 
8F
and funding.11 
9F
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
7.  Output 1: Organizational structure of the Greater Mekong Railway Association 
improved. A more formal structure with a clear mission, staffing, and business plan is essential. 
Recognizing the complexity in establishing the GMRA (with the involvement of GMS countries), 
 
8  The proposal to establish the GMRA was ratified at the 18th GMS Ministerial Meeting in Nanning, PRC on 12–13 
December 2012. ADB has served as the secretariat of the GMRA since its inception. The GMRA board of directors 
comprises six GMS member countries, with ADB as a member; ADB has been arranging funding for the GMRA as 
requested by the GMS countries. 
9  ADB. 2014. Technical Assistance for Support for Implementing the Action Plan for Transport and Trade Facilitation 
in the Greater Mekong Subregion. Manila (TA 8748-REG). On 26 October 2018, a draft Cross-Border Railway 
Transport Connectivity Agreement was agreed on among the GMS countries in Bangkok; a revised draft Cross-
Border Railway Transport Connectivity Agreement was sent to them on 21 January 2019 for their review and 
comments. 
10 ADB. 2011. The Greater Mekong Subregion Economic Cooperation Program Strategic Framework, 2012–2022. 
Manila. 
11 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

3 
the TA will undertake the following tasks, working in close consultation with the relevant GMRA 
working groups and railway representatives: (i) confirm the structure and improvement plan for 
the GMRA and draft charter based on the recommendations of ADB’s TA for Planning the Greater 
Mekong Subregion Railway Coordination Office in 2013 and as endorsed by the GMS countries 
in 2015; 12 (ii) develop draft governance principles, structure, and staffing needs for the GMRA 
10F
that will be discussed at a workshop with GMRA members  and subsequently refined in response 
to comments; (iii) develop a draft 3-year indicative costed business plan and proposed position 
descriptions for key staff to be discussed at a workshop, and subsequently refined in response to 
comments; and (iv) canvass options for the GMRA secretariat’s location and for funding the 
GMRA’s new secretariat and the initial period of the business plan. 
 
8.  While the TA cannot ensure that the preferred organizational structure of the GMRA is 
implemented and properly resourced, it will help improve the quality and timeliness of decision-
making by the current GMRA board by providing quality analysis and close consultation. 
 
9.  Output 2: Operational readiness plan for the Greater Mekong Railway Association 
developed. The TA will assist the GMRA, relevant working groups, and representatives of the 
national railway organizations to follow a structured process leading to the preparation of an 
operational readiness plan agreed to by all GMS countries that will underpin the development of 
the future modern GMS railway network. The operational readiness plan will address setting a 
timetable for (i) the introduction of modern railway technologies and standards, (ii) mainstreaming 
of sustainable railway infrastructure, (iii) the adoption of efficient railway operating practices, and 
(iv) the development of regional railway safety standards. The plan will also consider incorporating 
mitigation methods for addressing the environmental and social risks of railway link development. 
While the key issues for such a plan were identified by phase 1 of ADB’s TA for Connecting the 
Railways of the Greater Mekong Subregion (footnote 3), there needs to be a consensus by the 
national railway organizations on the implementation schedule and resourcing implications. 
 
10.  The TA will undertake to (i) confirm the scope of standards and technologies to be covered 
by the operational readiness plan based on the findings of phase 1 of ADB’s TA for Connecting 
the Railways of the Greater Mekong Subregion (footnote 3) at a  workshop with GMRA members; 
(ii) develop agreed principles for the introduction of standards and technologies recognizing the 
large legacy investments in national railway systems, noting that new railway corridors will use 
more advanced standards and technologies; (iii) collaboratively develop the framework for the 
operational readiness plan during the workshop; (iv) detail the (draft) operational readiness plan 
and cost it out based on the workshop; and (v) prepare the operational readiness plan based on 
comments from the GMRA and national railway organizations. 
 
11.  Output  3:  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  railway  network  development  strategy 
updated. The TA will update the current GMS railway strategy that was formulated in 2010 
(footnote 12). While the current GMS railway strategy has been effective, it needs updating so 
that network planning is in line with current national and regional development strategies, and so 
that it takes account of recent developments with respect to the missing GMS railway links and 
the identified priorities for future railway link development. 
 
12.  The TA will (i) update project priorities using economic and financial analysis based on 
updated demand projections (output 4) and costings, reflecting recommendations on standards 
and technology (output 2); (ii) update environmental and social screening of the priority projects; 
 
12 ADB. 2010. Technical Assistance for Planning the Greater Mekong Subregion Railway Coordination Office. Manila 
(TA 7678-REG). The TA assisted GMS countries in preparing a detailed plan for setting up the GMS Railway 
Coordination Office, including a business and a financing plan for its first 5 years of operation.

4 
 
(iii) conduct workshops on the findings of the priority projects to conceptualize an updated GMS 
railway development strategy; and (iv) update the costing and assessment of regional economic 
benefits. 
 
13.  Output 4: Updated Greater Mekong Subregion transport demand model prepared. 
The MRTM will provide traffic projections, which will form the foundation for economic and 
financial  analysis  to  aid  prioritization  and  inform  implementation  options.  Updated  demand 
projections are needed to support the development of the GMS railway network development 
strategy (output 3). The GMRA shall be the custodian of the MRTM and enable it to be used for 
more detailed project analysis. The following activities will be undertaken under the TA: (i) source 
data on freight and vehicle movements in relevant GMS corridors; (ii) improve the calibration of 
the MRTM; (iii) prepare new demand projections for various rail network options to support 
development of the new GMS railway network development strategy; (iv) document procedures 
for further data collection and processing, and updating of the MRTM; and (v) train GMRA and 
national railway organization staff in use of the demand model. 
 
14.  Output  5:  Bankable  railway  projects  identified  in  Greater  Mekong  Subregion 
countries. The TA will assist GMS countries to formulate bankable investment projects. It will 
help to conduct pre-feasibility studies and support the prioritization and initial conceptualization of 
investments. This will allow ADB and other GMS countries to scope out their potential support 
prior to full-fledged project preparation. 
 
15.  The TA will (i) update feedback on economic and financial analysis, using the new demand 
projections and new priorities identified under outputs 3 and 4; (ii) request GMS countries for 
project suggestions to be nominated for quick screening and/or inclusion in a pre-feasibility study; 
(iii) undertake pre-feasibility studies for the suggested projects; and (iv) identify projects for ADB 
financing and transaction TA planning. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
People's Republic of China Poverty Reduction and Regional Cooperation Fund and administered 
by ADB.13 The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. 
11F
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA. ADB will coordinate closely with the GMS 
member countries, national railway organizations, and the GMRA board of directors on all aspects 
of implementation of the TA. The GMRA’s working group on partnerships and GMRA operations 
will serve as the TA steering committee to support close coordination of national plans and 
priorities. The TA will be implemented over 24 months from January 2020 to December 2021. 
 
18.  ADB will manage the TA, with stakeholder oversight provided through the national rail 
organizations, each GMS country’s relevant agencies, and the GMRA. The TA findings will be 
disseminated to each GMS country through seminars and workshops, as well as to the GMRA 
working  group  meetings  and  general  meeting.  The  recommendations  on  the  preferred 
organizational structure, internal organizational development plan, and related aspects will be 
made to the GMRA board of directors through the fourth GMRA board of directors meeting 
(scheduled to take place in September 2020). A knowledge product highlighting the advanced

20.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions 
and/or staff instructions. Implementation will require 14 person-months of individual consultants 
in the core team. Output-based contracts will be used for study team consulting services when 
possible.14 
12F
 
21.  The GMRA members and ADB will develop and endorse specific terms of reference for 
each knowledge service. The consultants will have experience in their respective fields and 
demonstrate sound technical knowledge of railway planning, institutional development, and 
capacity building. 
 
22.  ADB will prepare periodic performance reports to monitor the design and monitoring 
framework indicators, including the quality of knowledge services.15 The reports will be presented 
13F
during GMRA workshops and meetings. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the Asian 
Development Bank administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 
to be financed on a grant basis by the People's Republic of China Poverty Reduction and Regional 
Cooperation Fund for Connecting the Railways of the Greater Mekong Subregion (Phase 2), and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.
